title: Gas Pain (Children)
author: WebMD Editorial Contributors

content: Gas pain is common in infants and children and rarely a cause for concern.

content_blocks.text: Gas pain is common in infants and children and rarely a cause for concern.

sections.heading: Call Doctor If:
bullets: Your child seems to have little energy.
Your child moves around much less than usual.
Your child can't be comforted or is inconsolable for two hours or more.
Your child regularly vomits after eating.
Your child has blood in their stool.
Your child's abdomen seems to be distended and causing pain.

Your child can't be comforted or is inconsolable for two hours or more.
Your child regularly vomits after eating.
Your child has blood in their stool.
Your child's abdomen seems to be distended and causing pain.

sections.heading: How to Treat Your Baby's Gas Pains
1. Adjust Feedings
bullets: Don't overfeed your child.
Hold them upright during and after feedings.
Burp your infant often.

items: Don't overfeed your child.
Hold them upright during and after feedings.
Burp your infant often.

sections.heading: 2. Move Your Child
bullets: Rock your child gently.
Move your child's legs as if they were pedaling a bicycle.

items: Rock your child gently.
Move your child's legs as if they were pedaling a bicycle.

sections.heading: 3. Massage Your Child
bullets: Rub your child's stomach lightly.
Lay them across your lap and pat their back.

items: Rub your child's stomach lightly.
Lay them across your lap and pat their back.

sections.heading: 4. Apply Warmth
bullets: Place a warm towel or water bottle on your child's tummy. (take care it is not too hot)

items: Place a warm towel or water bottle on your child's tummy. (take care it is not too hot)

sections.heading: 5. Review Feeding
bullets: If formula-feeding, talk with your pediatrician about switching to a soy-based formula or, if your child is older than 1 year, soy or almond milk. If an older child has gas pain after having milk products, talk to your doctor about lactose intolerance , especially if there is a family history of it.
If you're breastfeeding , you don't need to be concerned about your own diet causing gas pains in your baby. There's no evidence that a mom's diet has an effect on gas in babies.
